Posts.Content: Ah, Siani, another person whose cancer was spotted by a pet!  Me too.  It's an amazing and humbling thing to owe your life to an animal in that way, isn't it?   To start off with, you have a right to feel whatever feelings you feel.  They are yours.  However you react to having cancer, plus all the other medical stuff you have going on for you - that's the right way to react.  There's no wrong way to be with this.  I think you need to be authentic - you need to deal with the cancer in the way that is best for you. With friends like yours, to be honest, who needs enemies?  I often think that remarks like that ("wallowing" in cancer?  What, do they think it's like a hot bath or something??!) reflect fear on the part of the people who say them.  People think that if they can make you behave as if nothing's wrong, then you won't put any demands on them or make them feel bad about how little they may be doing for you.  There's also what I think of as the myth of positivity, too.  If I'd had a quid for every time I had the advice 'stay positive, it's the best thing to do to fight cancer', I'd be a rich woman.  Still p**sed off, mind, but rich. Perhaps you can train your kitten to fly at people who say such stupid things?  :-)
Posts.Title: Fed up

Posts.Content: Hello Moonriz!  I would say that if you don't feel a rapport with your consultant, that in itself would be enough to justify a second opinion.  You do need to trust him or her, and if you don't, then you'll always be slightly on your guard.  I agree that a big cancer centre would be a good place to head for, and I am sure that you will find someone with whom you click.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed should I get second opinion

Posts.Content: Wow, Kirstie, sounds like you are doing brilliantly with your new boob!  Rowing particularly - if you can do that, then clearly your function has not been affected much, since that does use your lats to a quite extraordinary extent.  It is very reassuring to hear your experiences.  My huge sheep are very friendly and well behaved, but are still much fitter and faster and stronger than me, so I need all the physical advantages I can possibly have when I'm dealing with them! Congenial, I'm sorry to hear that you've been worrying about this, and I'm really glad that my idle wondering has helped!  I guess that everyone's experiences are different, but it seems that many people have great results with whatever solution they go for.
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi there Gill, I'm sorry to find you here!  Alison gives very wise advice (especially the bit about the treats!)  I agree with her that this is the hardest time, and that Google is Not Your Friend under the circumstances.  Once your treatment starts properly, you will feel considerably better, I'm sure of it.  We're all here for you to talk to.  I went through the treatment 2 1/2 years ago and came out the other side, minus eyebrows (they never quite grew back after chemo) and I'm here to tell you that it's all doable.  Yes, there are some tricky moments, but your medical team will help you through.  Keep your chin up, and keep in touch!  All the very best.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Well, dear friends, I'm bowled over by your welcome!  Dreamthief, thank you for posting that - it is great fun to look back and see all of that media hoopla, and to remember what a hoot it all was.  Monika, I haven't had any chemo yet, the treatment has just been Denosumab, the hormone blockers Zolodex and Anastrozole, and a good zapping (that's the technical term) of radiotherapy.  I have told my consultant that I am minded to refuse chemo in the future, but I am pretty sure she'll still have a go at persuading me.   I don't normally think of myself as a determined or motivated person - perhaps I needed the cancer in order to force me to do the things I wanted to do.  But when our backs are against the wall, it's amazing what we can do.  I will never be free of the secondaries, but they don't rule me.
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: Aha, Helen, a fellow horse person!  I also have sheep - BIG sheep - hence the need for upper body strength...!  All interesting feedback, thank you very much.  I was extremely lucky with my entire medical team, who were all great, and continue to be a tremendous support - I know that's not always the case.  I haven't really asked them anything in detail about reconstructions, because I wanted to get the first 2 years out of the way first, but they did chat through the basics with me.  I don't think the hospital where I was treated carry out the DIEP reconstruction, but apparently if that was what I wanted, they would happily refer me on.  At the moment, I think it all seems too much hassle, but I am definitely reserving the right to change my mind in the future.  At least with the DIEP reconstruction, they'd be relocating something I definitely don't use and would be glad to lose...
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Oh dear.  That's sad that your surgeon was pushing you towards the implants.  Mine said that they wouldn't recommend implants for patients like me because the results aren't as good - interesting how the advice we are all given varies so much, isn't it?  Interestingly, everyone I spoke to at the hospital told me that having a reconstruction means that you may have an ongoing relationship with the plastic surgeons for the rest of your life, as implants don't last forever and reconstructed boobs don't age in quite the same way as natural ones, so may need some attention later.  My husband's lack of squeamishness has never ceased to amaze me.  The first time my dressing was changed after the surgery, he helped the nurse do it, and has been completely unbothered by the whole thing.  And I've never worn a bikini in my life, and I don't think I'll be starting to do that now!!  One of my main concerns was that, with a large chunk of muscle taken from my back, I would not be able to sit squarely and centrally on my horse - important for a classical dressage rider - but would be unbalanced.  At least my prosthesis weighs the same as a real boob, and so far the horse hasn't noticed the difference!  I have ample spare tyre to work with, although it's rapidly going down now - I put on a lot of weight during the treatment which is now shifting (another reason why I didn't want to have an immediate reconstruction). One day, maybe.  It's nice to know that the options are there, should I want them.
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Greetings all I had a mastectomy last year (right side only) without a reconstruction.  I've healed extremely well, my surgeon (who I love - I'm incredibly lucky to have been treated by him) has made it clear that I can just request a reconstruction when and if I want to - but I have some nagging worries about the options available.  Principally, I am concerned about what it's like to have a large chunk of your back muscles 'repurposed' - in the long term, that is.  Does it affect your strength and functioning?  Does it make you feel lop-sided?  Can you still do all the things that you could do before?   I'm assured by the hospital staff that most people don't notice a difference, but I have quite an active lifestyle - and it's not as if I can have the op reversed if I don't like the effect!  ("No, I'm sorry, I don't like it - can you put those muscles back where you got them, please?") I'm not ruling out having the surgery, but I must admit that, at the moment, I'm leaning towards not bothering.  I've been quite surprised at how little I've been bothered by only having one breast, I like my prosthesis, and I have an awesome bra collection (much better than I had pre-surgery) - plus the fact that I've got trashed veins from the chemo I had, and have had quite enough of hospital visits to last me a very long time.  I guess there are options other than an LD reconstruction, but my surgery team have indicated that they think I'll be a good candidate for this method. I'd be really glad to hear personal experiences from people here, if you care to share.  Thanks folks!
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hello friends Been a while since I dropped by, and I thought, hey, I'd better let you all know that I am still alive!  Having been diagnosed with secondaries in my bones just about a year ago, I went through some horrible months where I couldn't walk, could hardly get out of bed, and thought that the outlook was pretty grim, but now I am up and at 'em!  I'm walking well - I can walk all day long, over rough ground - and I don't get especially tired.  I'm back to shepherding (which was my consultant's main  goal - little did she know what it actually entails, but we won't tell her that) and I have defrosted my business (it was well and truly on ice whilst I was ill) and am now bulldozing it into success.  I sometimes feel like I am powering myself with just willpower alone, but it's working, and I feel great.  I've had to make some concessions, sure, but I'm trying to do that as gracefully as I can. Good to see some of my old friends here, and to see some new names too.  We're all survivors, each and every one of us.  There's a lot of life to still be lived, even with a scary diagnosis, and I intend to live it fully.  May we all do the same!
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: I can so relate to what you say, Intrepid.  I've been on Tamoxifen for nearly 3 years now, and over the last few months I've noticed that I am much more prone to muscle sprains and strains, cramps and ligament injuries.  It's all soft tissue stuff, but I get injured more easily and it takes longer to heal.  I'm laid up at the moment with a stubborn groin strain which just isn't going away.  I wonder whether there are any ways we can stay on Tamoxifen and get the benefit of it, but get rid of this horrible stiffness?  I have put myself onto a regime of cod liver oil and regular stretches, but it's too early to say whether this will be helpful.  I am increasingly hating Tamoxifen and am wondering whether I should take the risk of having a shorter, better quality life, rather than feeling like this all the time.
Posts.Title: Hip pain - any ideas?

Posts.Content: Ah, the joy of having a tooth abscess.  I've had a grumbling bit of infection in the root of one of my teeth for ages, but it has decided to flare up this weekend just gone (why is it always out of hours why whywhywhyarrrggghhh).  The infection has blown through my jawbone, so it doesn't actually hurt any more, but the side of my face has swollen up to a ludicrously massive size.  I'm a tad concerned that, if the tooth has to come out, I'll have to stop the Denosumab for a while... apparently there are some problems with bleeding sockets if you're still on the stuff when you have to have extractions.  It would be richly ironic (and not in a good way) if my teeth, the bane of my existence as they have always been, prevent me from keeping on with an effective cancer treatment.  Grrrr. Still!  The dentist doesn't want to take the tooth out.  He gazed wistfully at the x-ray and said 'look at that beautiful crown, it's a work of art.  It would be such a terrible shame to extract that...' The antibiotics are kicking in... hopefully tomorrow I will not look so much like a rodent...
Posts.Title: Best hamster impression EVAH!!!

Posts.Content: Judith, these are FANTASTIC - the ewe with the two middle teeth only looks extremely sinister, I have to say.  One of our oldest ewes, Norah, has got so few teeth left that she has earned herself the nickname Gummer.  The vet gave her her annual check-up and said brightly, 'well, she's still got half her teeth!'  That was 2 years ago, so I bet she's a bit more dentally challenged now.   I am glad to say that the metronidazole has kicked in and I am remarkably better now.  No need for any further dental treatment, and hopefully I can have my Denosumab next week, only a week late but that isn't catastrophic when you've been on it for a while.  Phew.
Posts.Title: Best hamster impression EVAH!!!

Posts.Content: Tee hee - thanks all!  I must admit that I'm very fond of my prosthesis.  It's an excellent match in shape for my remaining boob, it is super-comfortable (I don't notice I've got it on most of the time), it sits in my bra and is never any problem, and I even find that, if I touch it, I feel the touch on my chest wall - it's not quite as if it has nerves of its own, but nearly!   I shall take your advice and have a chat to my BCN - always a pleasure, as she is extremely nice.
Posts.Title: There's a hole in my prosthesis, dear Liza, dear Liza...

Posts.Content: Oh gosh, yes, I'd forgotten about this particular side effect!  I used to find that my mind would be racing - you know, sometimes, if there's something wrong with your computer and you have to reboot it, you get text scrolling up the screen, too fast for you to read?  Occasionally it stops, and you can read what's on the screen, then it just goes racing on again.  That was what my mind was like on FEC.  I would wake up in the lucid periods, with my entire crazy dream momentarily making sense to me, then whoosh - my mind would accelerate and that lucidity would be lost.   The weirdest dream I had, though, was shortly after I had been diagnosed.  I dreamed that I was in a small room somewhere, talking to my immune system (I had been very concerned with looking after it so that it would fight the cancer).  It was rather like a Labrador puppy - no attention span, into everything, very playful.  I said to it, "look, about this cancer.  What can I do to help you fight it?"  It stopped whatever it was doing and said "Cancer?  What cancer?  Oh my God!!" and then disappeared, presumably to go and deal with it. Like I said, it was a very weird dream.
Posts.Title: Weird dreams

Posts.Content: ...and it's filling with water when I wash it!!!  I've had it for about 18 months now, and I wear it every day, so I guess it gets some wear and tear.  The water has obviously found a way into it through a tiny hole in the plastic coating.  I was thinking of going swimming this week, but perhaps that might not be a good idea.  I'd go into the water looking like a perfectly balanced C cup, and come out with one side a G!   For those of us who have prosthetic boobs (no reconstruction for me), how long do they last you?  Do you have more than one?  Do you like yours?
Posts.Title: There's a hole in my prosthesis, dear Liza, dear Liza...

Posts.Content: Yes, this happened to me too - I ended up having a lumpectomy and lymph nodes removed, then chemo, then a mastectomy, because I had what the surgeon termed an 'unstable breast' (sounds like it was going to explode!) and he hadn't managed to get wide enough margins. In the event, I had lots of pre-cancerous cells, plus quite a few specks of actual cancer which the chemo hadn't mopped up, so it was actually a good call by my team.
Posts.Title: Further surgery for 'wider margins' and more lymph nodes to be re

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane Yes, I can relate to this.  I felt quite terrible for weeks after finishing my chemo.  The drugs are still frolicking around in your system, even now, so you're still feeling the effects.  You could well be anaemic - I was, hideously so, after the chemo had finished, and it took a long time to put that right.  BUT.  I just wanted to let you know that when I started to feel better, I felt MUCH better, very quickly.   If you're worried, I think it'd be worth ringing your breast care nurse - I did that when I was in the same situation, and she really put my mind at rest.  I know what you mean about not wanting to bother your GP, but the BCN is there for just such eventualities! Get plenty of rest, and take heart - this too shall pass, and you'll feel much better in a very short time. All the best
Posts.Title: Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Crikey, yes, I have had so many good things come out of having cancer.  Before, I was a rather directionless individual who used to drift along, never really committing to anything, and pretty much convinced that nothing I actually did in my life would have any effect - I had no conception of my own personal power, if you like.  I think, in a way, I needed to have cancer in order to find out that I do have agency in my life, that I can create the things I want.  It's also given me a deadline (I have secondaries) which has really made me get on with things!  I have made some wonderful friends who I otherwise would never have known; there's a group of people who now help us with our flock of sheep, and for two of them in particular this has been life-changing.  They'd never have got this opportunity without me having cancer either. I mean, I'd rather not have had it, of course... but I'd be a vastly different person without it.
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Mandi!  Getting through all that surgery, chemo and rads means that you are awesome!  I know it probably doesn't feel that way at the moment.  I am so sorry that you feel frustrated and fed up - it's hardly surprising, though.  The time immediately after treatment finishes can be very strange and unsettling - I know I found it so, and I didn't have the full monty like you have (surgery and chemo only).  I found it was like being in no-man's land.  I didn't have cancer any more (that was how I thought of it) but I certainly wasn't well.  But I slowly clawed my way back to something like normality, and I am confident that you will too.   All the very best

Posts.Content: Hahahah, these are EXCELLENT!  I love the black and white knitted design, it's very clever.  And the well-dressed sheep look very dapper.   Ahhh, sheep.  I love them.
Posts.Title: Sheep Count too.. For Emma P. :-)

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting this, George and Jackie!  I'm still not sure whether I can be bothered to go through the whole reconstruction thing (you can tell I'm not one of those who has been overly traumatised by losing a breast, can't you?) but it's really great to have all that info in one place, and from such a reputable source as our favourite hosts Macmillan.  Time for a read, I think... All the best
Posts.Title: Facing or Thinking About Reconstruction ?

Posts.Content: Oh dear.  It isn't just a difficult and confusing time for humans, is it - it's definitely puzzling for pets as well.  I remember my horse being hugely confused with my hair loss, since he really enjoys whiffling my hair extremely gently with his nose.  The day after my husband shaved my head, the horse pushed my hat to one side as he normally would, encountered bald skin, and was most taken aback. (He was very suspicious of my wig, too.)  I am sure that your dogs will soon settle - and it is good for them (and for you) to let them comfort you.  Dogs are great at that.   I'm sorry that you aren't having a good day, too.  I'm sending you hugs.
Posts.Title: I have just upset the dog

Posts.Content: Trudi, I am so sorry.  This sounds horrendous.  You are more than entitled to whinge - to go outside and shake your fist at the sky and scream WHY ME, UNIVERSE??!! at the top of your lungs.  That might be cathartic, although I cannot guarantee that your neighbours won't think you've taken leave of your senses.   So, to get on to the topic of your family.  I really understand that it is hard for them to deal with or think about cancer, and the fact that you are going through this means that they have to face the facts of your mortality, their own mortality, their helplessness in the face of illness, all that stuff.  I know all of that, and to them I say, with full respect and love: F*ck that shit.  They are not stepping up to the plate.  The situation is really awkward - you are feeling very awkward and upset about it, and they are going on their merry way.  If you ask me, the awkwardness needs to be transferred to the correct place - to them.  It is not your awkwardness - it comes from them.  You have lots of ways to do that, but you will need to say to yourself that HERE are your boundaries, the things you expect, and that it's OK for you to have those expectations, and that if your relatives are called out on their inconsiderate behaviour, they might not like you for it.   How you call them out is up to you.  You just need to do something - anything - to change the dynamic between you.  You could talk to them in a rational way.  (That is preferable - remember to use the formula 'when you do x I feel y', rather than OMGYOUINCONSIDERATEGITSYOU'REALWAYSREALLYHORRIBLEANDI'VEALWAYSHATEDYOU!!!!)  You could let fly with your justifiable anger and fury at them.  This might drive them away, but it would make you feel better.  It might also make them think that you are a little deranged, but that might be OK.  There is a school of thought that would say it should be your husband who calls his sister out on this one - she is his blood relative, and sort of more his responsibility than yours.  That can sometimes work, but it requires husband to also be outraged at his sister's behaviour.  If he isn't, then that could be opening too much of a can of worms. I think it would also be worthwhile knowing exactly what you DO want them to do for you.  What would perfect behaviour from your sister-in-law look like?  She may have no idea what to do, and you may have to ask very specifically for what you want.  Yes yes, I know this is hard, you've never done it before, and it is outrageously unfair that you have to do it, but she's obviously not getting it.  What do you want your sister to do?  Your family?  If they are still expecting you to cook and clean for them whilst you are going through treatment, they need to know that that's not going to happen.  Remember that emotional blackmail is your friend throughout all of this.  (Yes, I am prepared to do whatever it takes, I am afraid - I have secondary cancer and potentially a short time to live, and I actually don't give a shit any more.) Ooops - I have to go to the hospital myself for an appointment (now where is my special Hospital Waiting Room Knitting??)  Remember, Trudi, we have your back, we are here, and we understand.  Come back, rant often, rant at length.  We will always listen.
Posts.Title: I am experienceing anger at my family andfeel awful about it

Posts.Content: Oh Stumble, I'm so sorry.  It is a really weird thing, suddenly having the world and his wife staring at your boobs, isn't it?  I think this may be an indication that the rapport you have with your surgeon isn't everything it could be - nobody's fault, but I think it's an indication that you need to have more women on your team.  I appreciate that it's really awkward telling them how you feel, but think of it this way - if you are feeling reluctant to see your surgeon, this could impact on your recovery.  Nobody wants that. I am absolutely certain that you won't be the first woman to feel this way - and you won't be the last.   All the very best
Posts.Title: I feel...violated?

Posts.Content: I think eyelashes grow rather slowly, and I'm not sure how to encourage them to hurry up and grow already, dammit!!  Did anyone else suffer from ingrowing hairs as they were all growing back?  The very fine hairs on my arms were the worst for that. I had an absolutely killer wig which fooled many, many people.  To be honest it sort of fooled me too - I could indulge in a spot of denial when I had it on, which was nice.  I really wanted an extravagantly long pink one, but just didn't have the energy to go looking for one, which was a shame really.
Posts.Title: Eyelashes

Posts.Content: Hey, that site is great!  The selection is amazing.  My hair is back now, as thick and opinionated as ever, and I am hoping I will never need a wig again - but if I do... I know where to go!
Posts.Title: Eyelashes

Posts.Content: Wow, Kimberley.  I'm so sorry to hear of your troubles.  I get the most terrible sense of your desperation from your post, and my heart goes out to you.  I am not sure what advice I can give, because this is a tangle which has been many years in the making.  I also don't have children, so I can only have an intellectual understanding of your relationship with your daughter, not a gut feeling about it.   My first thought is that you need to look after yourself and your husband.  Physically speaking, Tamoxifen side effects can be very wearing, and I wonder whether there's anything that can be done to help deal with those.  A trip to your doctor might well help there. Your husband may well not be able to come up with solutions to this tangle, but I think you should keep talking to him about it.  It is hurt which is affecting both of you, and by sharing it, you keep the lines of communication open.  Make sure that there is no blame in your discussions though - it's not your fault and it's not his fault, it's something that has happened, and you can't turn back the clock.  (I'm from a farming background, and the agricultural attitude of 'shit happens - now let's deal with it' has stood me in good stead in my life!) I think it would be a great idea for you to find a counsellor, someone who is well outside your family dynamic who can be an independent ear for you to talk to.  You are right in the middle of a horrible mess, and I know from experience that it is incredibly valuable to talk to someone who can help you get some perspective on matters.   The business about your daughter leaving her partner and returning to him again rings some alarm bells.  I think it would be worthwhile reading a book called The Gift of Fear, by Gavin De Becker.  There's a lot in there which is completely irrelevant (although the theory De Becker suggests, of trusting your instincts, is relevant in almost any area of our lives!) but there's some interesting stuff about people who return to difficult relationships.  It might give an insight into what's happening, it might not. I'm so sorry that you have all this on your plate.  Your cancer treatment was really not all that long ago - I know I don't feel fully recovered yet, and it's over 2 years since I finished my treatment - and it is a cruel fate which has given you all this to deal with too.  You're in my thoughts. All the very best
Posts.Title: URGENTLY NEED HELP......ANOTHER ANGLE OPINION...PLEASE

Posts.Content: Oh dear me, I'd forgotten about this side effect!  I bled constantly for the whole time I was on FEC.  Not heavily, mind, but it was annoying.  My oncologist said it's not common, but not unheard-of.  I do have fibroids, and there was some thought that it might have had something to do with them - or as a result of having a lowered red blood cell count.  It did stop once I was onto the taxotere part of the treatment, which was a relief!
Posts.Title: Periods on fec-t

Posts.Content: When I was at university, the dad of one of my friends was a consultant anaesthetist.  He told me that traces of the anaesthetic drugs they were using then (1990-ish) could be in your system for up to a year afterwards!  So to me, this is plausible.  (And 9 hours - whew!  That's a long time on the table.) Whatever it is, I hope you feel better very soon.
Posts.Title: anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Hey there Rhonda, I'm sorry that you are having a bad time at the moment.  You've certainly thrown some firepower at your BC, and I have every confidence that you will still be here in 5 years - and 10 years!   Knowing or not knowing the stats - that's a very personal decision, isn't it?  I didn't want to know what they were, but the key question I asked my surgeon was 'is there any reason why I shouldn't be in the group of patients who get rid of their cancer and are never troubled by it again?'  (He said 'no reason - you're very boring I'm afraid, nothing unusual about you.'  I love him.)  That question seems a little less stark than wanting the bald figures, but for some folk, seeing the numbers would be more of a comfort. You are pretty amazing to have come through the ordeal that you have undergone.  I am in awe of you!  All the very best
Posts.Title: triple positive breast cancer

Posts.Content: Of all the things I went through during my treatment, I think these tests made me the most nervous (not helped by the fact that I tend to faint when cannulas are inserted into my veins, which I duly did, much to the lovely radiographer's discomfort).  But the actual scans themselves aren't a problem at all.  The bone scan was quite relaxing; the bed moves through the machine very slowly, and although you have to lie very still, it isn't a problem.  I was astonished at how quick the CT scan is.  You're in and out in a trice.  I found the explanation of how the scanners work was very interesting, and distracted me nicely.   Sending you hugs, anyway.  None of this stuff is how we would choose to spend our time, is it!
Posts.Title: Bone and CT scans

Posts.Content: I have no idea either!  But you could take them as a suggestion for some of your lucky lottery numbers this week... :-)
Posts.Title: understanding discharge summary

Posts.Content: Oh Karen, Louise is very wise.  This level of pain is not good.  You haven't lifted something heavy and pulled your chest wall muscles, have you?  I did that and it hurt like a good 'un.  I even had what the oncologist thought at first was a sinister lump, but it turned out to just be a protesting muscle... But the point is, you need to go to the doctor and have it checked out.  Otherwise you won't know for sure.  And it is completely your choice.  But if you choose to continue to be someone who doesn't do doctors, you may have to accept that you might become someone with a problem which has not been caught early.  And that has big consequences.   I love Louise's advice to treat yourself as if you are your own best friend.  Please Karen - you have asked us for our help and advice, and this is my advice - go and see your GP, or phone your BCN tomorrow.  You are completely worth this.   And if my pleas don't cut the mustard, how about a threat?  Go tomorrow or I'll send my ginger kitten round to claw your curtains.  :-)
Posts.Title: please help

Posts.Content: Hello Amy I am so sorry that you have got this worry.  In my experience (I did actually have breast cancer), this early stage was the most worrying time.  If you're an imaginative person, your mind can really go to town.  Funnily enough, when I found out that I did actually have breast cancer, it was a strange relief!   You might find that you get all sorts of scans when you get to hospital - ultrasound, mammogram, the lot.  So I think it's worth preparing for that, otherwise it can be a bit intimidating!  You might not get the result straight away, either.   Whatever happens, you WILL be OK.  It's all unknown to you at the moment, but if you need to have some treatment, you will find that there will be people who will help you through.   Let us know your results, won't you?  I'll be thinking about you the day of your appointment. All the best
Posts.Title: Worried to the Maximum!

Posts.Content: Oh Jude, I wish I could crawl down the broadband line and give you a hug.  Your fear and worry absolutely leaps out of your posts - and of course it does, this is an extremely scary time.  We hear you.  Life is so bloody unfair sometimes.  When I had breast cancer a few years ago, one of the nurses told me that it doesn't just happen to the patient - it happens to everyone in that patient's web of family and friends.  My husband reckons that, in a way, it's easier to be the one who's having the treatment than the one who has to stand by and see their beloved relative going through it all.  He felt incredibly helpless. I need to tell you something about having brothers and sisters.  I have two sisters.  I love them both, but we are not at all close, and neither of them were a support to me when I was ill.  I would just like to let you know that brothers and sisters aren't all they are cracked up to be, sometimes!  I hope that will make you feel that being an only child is not such a disaster.   It is perfectly OK to feel however you feel about your mum's illness.  I don't think there is a right way or a wrong way to feel at this point.  Your feelings might change very quickly, too - one moment you might be feeling despairing, the next you might feel much more positive.  I think you just have to let that happen.  If you feel you have to push people away, then do so.  If you want to talk to people, then we are always here.  You may find (as I did) that friends come to you whilst you are going through all this, people who you don't know now, or perhaps you hardly know them.  It is hard to just not care about what people think of you (I still have trouble with this, and I am 43!) and I don't have any top tips on how to do this.  When you are younger, you'll find that many of your friends have no life experience, and they really haven't got a clue about how to get through a difficult time.  This may make them say cruel and thoughtless things.  (Mind you, plenty of older people are the same!) If it is any comfort, I can tell you from my experience that the early days of the cancer 'journey' are the hardest.  Once your mum gets into the treatments, things are somehow easier to get your head around.  You know where you are going, you know how you have to get there, and that's a definite comfort.  Some of the treatments are physically a challenge, but you kind of get used to the idea of them and then it's just a question of slogging through it. I think that you need to find someone who you can talk to, to tell them how you feel, rant if you need to, let off steam so that you can support your mum.  I have had a good experience phoning the Macmillan helpline (the phone number's plastered all over this website) and I wonder whether they might be able to help you?  They don't know you, and sometimes I think that's helpful because they can see your situation clearly.  And of course they are used to talking to people about this sort of issue all the time, whereas a lot of people we know in our lives just aren't. ajhdfjdsh  Oops, my ginger kitten has just arrived on my keyboard and randomly hit some keys.  I'll leave what he wrote here, just in case he's trying to send you his love too.  I'll keep you and your mum in my thoughts.  Keep in touch.  You and your mum will come out of this OK, but you will be changed by it, as we all are.  I look on my bout of cancer as a real turning point in my life - and good has come of it, believe it or not. Much love

Posts.Content: Hi there MamaSm The best piece of advice I can give you is to ask for a PICC line.  It's a line which goes into a vein in your arm and stays there for the duration of your chemo.  It means that you don't have to keep having cannulas shoved into your veins, and you can also have blood taken through it.  They put it in under local anaesthetic, and I really couldn't feel a thing when I had mine put in.  It's brilliant.   Also, drink plenty of water, take whatever anti-sickness tablets they give you even if you aren't sick, and take heart.  This too shall pass.  Stay away from Cadbury's mini-eggs, they have a peculiarly addictive quality when combined with FEC chemo.  (That's a medical discovery I made myself - my oncologist was very impressed.) You'll be OK! All the best

Posts.Content: Hello there H! Cool!  The lumps are benign.  You are definitely much further forward than you were 24 hours ago.  This is an excellent thing to know.   They have given you the number of a breast care nurse precisely because you do not know the system!  That's her (in my experience, usually it's a woman) job, to help you navigate it.  If you need to speak to the doctor, the BCN will help you with that.  They are usually available during office hours, so you can phone on Monday morning and get some advice.  My BCN was very interested in everything to do with my treatment, and also in getting to know me as a person.  She was the most amazingly helpful guide to the whole thing.  It's a shame you didn't manage to meet yours today.   I had wondered how much information you would actually be getting today.  It was my experience that one lot of tests would lead to another, but it would take a while before I got the whole picture.  You may also find that, even though the lumps are benign, they may want to do something about them anyway ("we don't like lumps" said my surgeon) - in my case, they wanted to make sure there was nothing lurking behind them (there was).  But I had a real live, bona fide cancerous lump as well, so they knew that all was not OK.  Things might be different for you. It is very hard to cultivate a sort of attitude where you are in suspended animation, almost - waiting without any attachment to the result.  I don't think that gets much easier with practice. Take care, keep in touch
Posts.Title: Friday the 13th is upon me - feeling lonely

Posts.Content: Oh Kim, I'm so sorry to hear that you're finding it tough.  The others are right - it is really important to keep the lines of communication open.  Keep talking about things, no matter how uncomfortable they are.   I'd also like to let you know that, in my experience, once you start chemo it becomes easier.  In fact, the further along the journey you get, the challenges change.  I found it a lot less hard mentally, but more of a physical challenge.  It is as if you know more about the cancer, so the fear of the unknown recedes, and all you have to do is keep showing up for treatments, get your head down, and plod through.   Keep us posted, won't you - we understand, we've been there!   All the best
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry to hear about your sister's news.  It's really hard when someone close to you is going through this.  We are all in a web of relationships and kinships, and this sort of serious challenge affects the entire web.  I think it is definitely worth acknowledging this.  Of course, it's not all about you, but some of it is, and you need to make sure that you yourself have someone to sound off to, if you need it.  Have you asked your sister what she would like you to do?  My parents were desperate to be of assistance when I was ill, but some of their help did backfire.  They decided that they would do our laundry, despite the fact that we were having no trouble getting through the washing.  I foolishly said yes, so they took a huge load of our laundry back to their house, 80 or so miles away, to wash it and return it the following week.  Of course, it was the middle of winter, the frost and snow came down, and they couldn't get back to see us for weeks.  My clean clothes were stranded in Bedfordshire for quite a while!  I would have preferred them to do shopping for me, or just to sit with me and entertain me whilst I was feeling fragile after the chemo.  But I didn't feel I could ask. I think that it is hard to make any concrete plans about what to do during chemo, because everyone reacts differently.  I had some great ideas about what I was going to eat, only to find that I couldn't keep it down, or it upset my tummy, or it tasted horrid because I had a constant metallic taste in my mouth.  I also found that I got obsessive cravings for some things - avocados, of all things, with oil and vinegar dressing.  I couldn't have predicted that one! When I was ill, I found that what I really wanted from the people around me was truth.  It is good to be strong for the person who is ill, but during the times when my husband was finding things difficult, I wanted to know.  It made our relationship that much stronger.  I think that if you don't show your emotions, it can come across as being uncaring, even if you are doing it for the best possible reasons.  But you will know what will best help your sister. I would like to reassure you that chemo is very doable, and although it is unpleasant (sometimes very unpleasant!) there are many unexpected moments of lightness and hope along the way.  I learned a lot about myself, and about my friends and family.  Breast cancer is so treatable these days, and I am sure that your sister will come out the other side. Keep us posted - and if your sister wants to come and talk to us as well, it would be great to 'see' her here! All the best

Posts.Title: Nearly 1 year on - why am I crying?

Posts.Content: Hey Mandy, sorry to hear all of this (although well done for getting through 5 sessions of chemo, you are kicking the cancer's arse here!)  The reaction you describe is one which will have us veterans of BC treatment nodding our heads in recognition.  In a strange way, going through treatment is the easy bit, because you're on the conveyor belt, there's a recognised path for you, and you know what's coming next.  (Of course it's not at all easy, because nausea and vomiting and blood tests and sleepless nights and worry and loss of hair and and and, but you know what I mean.)  I think that it has been recognised by many oncology teams that the end of treatment has its own peculiar challenges, and there is help out there to get your head round what has happened.  It sometimes takes your mind quite a long time to catch up with the reality of what has occurred, so you might want to watch out for that too.   My sister posted a Useful Motto onto Facebook the other day.  It said 'Don't believe the things you tell yourself late at night.'  Those 3am thoughts seem like reality, but they are not.  They are just an interpretation of reality, seen through the lens of sleeplessness and loneliness.  They have a power over us, why I know not, but they are no more or less true than the daytime thoughts which say 'I will be OK after this'.   And howling at the moon sounds a great idea, especially if your dog will join you.  Go on - I bet you'll feel better afterwards!!
Posts.Title: 5th Chemo done 1 more to go , should be happy .....but

Posts.Content: Hey New2This, I'm sorry to see you here, but as everyone says, we are a super friendly bunch.  Whatever is happening to you at the moment, someone here will be able to empathise.  Chemo does dish out a whole load of surprise 'gifts', doesn't it?  When my fingernails started to flake, I painted them with a thick layer of nail varnish and tried to pretend it wasn't happening.  It sort of glued them back together again.  Don't worry about not noticing what was happening to you - that is an extremely common experience.  I was so clueless that it took one of my sheep to point it out!  (Google 'Alfie Cancer Sheep' and you'll find out what happened.)   I'm sending you a big hug, and my flock send you woolly hugs as well.  You'll get through.  Keep talking to us!  I don't know what time zone you're in, but if you're not in the UK, bear with us Brits - it might be the middle of the night for us!  But we will wake up the next morning and we will reply.

Posts.Content: Hello Kittycat I felt pretty rubbishy for a few weeks after my last Docetaxol treatment, and those weeks felt never-ending.  But I noticed that when I started to feel better, the improvements stacked up quickly.  I think everyone's different, but I hope that you will share my experience!  It was very heartening to find that I felt better day after day, rather than week after week. Posts.Title: Giving up Tomoxifen, right to wrong?

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, that all sounds like it was pretty horrendous!  I can understand why you have given it up.  I would like to share my experience of Tamoxifen, though, which was that I had some pretty dire hot flushes and night sweats to start with, but these settled down within a couple of months, then I was side-effect free.  Three weeks isn't really long enough for your body to have got used to the drug.  I have my own quarrel with Tamoxifen, but I have to say that I did get used to it.
Posts.Title: Giving up Tomoxifen, right to wrong?

Posts.Content: Hey Julie, I'm so sorry to hear that you are struggling right now.  I'm 2 years post initial diagnosis almost to the day (wow - how'd that go by so fast??!) and I am still affected by what happened.  I went to see my lovely GP the other day, and spoke to her about how I feel - about 6 weeks ago, I woke up one morning and thought "What the hell happened to me?  Where's my BOOB gone??  Why have I got all these scars??  What happened to my EYEBROWS??  Why's my HAIR all curly???  WAAAHHHH!!!"  My GP said that she thinks it can take your mind a long time to catch up with what happened to your physical body, and once it does (a long time down the road, sometimes) it can seem very strange because, well, the treatment happened such a long time ago.  I have an appointment in 10 days or so to see a counsellor, which I think will be most useful. If I might say so, I think that it is hardly surprising that you are finding it hard to be positive.  You have had a terrible medical adventure which affects you to this day, and you have lost a close member of your family recently.  It would be a miracle if you could come up smiling after that double whammy.  Things will get better - as I often find myself saying, this too shall pass.  Nothing that you feel in this situation is wrong - you have a right to feel your feelings, and I believe that being relentlessly positive is too much of a burden.   I'm sending you a load of hugs.  I'm sure that Kate's right about ringing the MacMillan helpline - it would be good to get an expert perspective on this.  You will be OK. Much love

Posts.Title: Fantastic News and thank you

Posts.Content: Oh Yvonne, I'm so sorry that you are having to go through this.  It's miserable, isn't it?  You'll probably find you'll get upset at random times and over random things - I remember that happening to me.  I think that the key is to recognise that this is your own way of dealing with things, and the upset needs to come out some time.  If it's any comfort, I think that this is the worst time - when you don't know the whole picture.  Once your treatment starts, there's a clear path for you to follow and you will be all right. Your comment about going shopping and everyone else being 'normal' reminds me of something my husband said, after all my treatment was over and I was getting better.  He said that when he travels on the Tube, or is in a crowd of people, he looks at the women near him and wonders whether they are breast cancer patients or survivors too.  After all, 1 in 8 of us will have a brush with it during our lives, so statistically there are bound to be people on that train, or on that escalator, who have gone through what we are going through now.  They look 'normal' too... He said it was a comfort to him, to think that there are thousands of women who have gone through all the treatment and are now getting on with their lives.  I think it's an interesting thing to remember - you never know what is going on for other people.  After all, I bet nobody else out shopping with you that afternoon could possibly have known what was happening for you. I'm thinking of you and wishing you all the best for your treatment.  The chances are that you will come through and be fine.  We're here for you. Much love

Posts.Title: Confused now

Posts.Content: It's funny, isn't it, but when I thought I just had a busted ligament, my leg wasn't that painful.  Now I know it's bone mets, it's excruciating.  My GP, though, has been most generous with the prescription pad, and I now have THREE (count 'em) different sorts of painkillers to take!  I haven't been hugely active in the last few days because I've been feeling rather swimmy-headed with the co-codamol, but that's settling down now and I am having to force myself to move.  I have bone and CT scans next Thursday, my family and friends are rallying around magnificently, and over on the Facebook page where our sheep blog (yes, really!), the whole community has mobilised for me.   My mind is not letting me think about the implications of this at all.  Every time I get close to thinking about it, my thought process gets diverted at the speed of light into something innocuous like 'oh, look at the lovely daffodils' or 'what do I fancy for my dinner?' or 'I must pay the vets' bill'.  Denial, my friends, ain't just a river in Egypt. But for those of you who are just starting out on the journey, know that I am very unusual!  The likelihood is that you will never be bothered by your cancer again, and all will be well for you.  And even if you fall into the small group who get a revisit of the cancer, it's all treatable.  I'm just waiting for that process to start. All the best, my friends
Posts.Title: A Smorgasbord of Drugs

Posts.Content: I had my hair dyed pink before it all fell out, on the principle that it didn't matter if the dye damaged it, it was gonna go anyway!  I had a really edgy, funky short crop done about a week before it all fell out, and then my husband shaved my head.  I never looked at my bald head in the mirror - used to avoid looking at myself if I didn't have my wig on.  Wig was absolutely brilliant, and fooled ALL the people ALL the time.  My one regret was that I didn't go for something a bit wilder in the wig department... Posts.Content: Hi Tracey I was in that place in the summer.  I had lost a pet who had been very important in getting me through my illness, and I was convinced that my mammogram would show up something sinister (it was 2 years after my treatment ended).  I think that mammograms spark off a kind of short-circuit in our memories which slams us straight back into the treatment and how hideous it was.  I am sorry that this is so hard for you.  It sounds like you threw absolutely everything at your cancer last year, and you did amazingly well to get through it.  It is hardly surprising that this is freaking you out.   I spoke to the nurses on the Macmillan Support Line, and also to the breast care nurse at the hospital about my worries, and I think that might be a worthwhile thing to do if you can. It is a remarkable thing that you have done - that all of us have done - to get through the ordeal of treatment and to come out the other side.  You are brave and powerful and you WILL get through this, whatever happens. (My mammogram worked out fine - all clear, thankfully.  And I'm sure yours will too.  The stats are on your side in this, after all.  But I know that may not be much comfort right now.)

Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: I conferred this status upon myself at the start of this year, when I went back to the hospital for a 6-monthly check-up with my surgeon and found that the hospital had completely changed the layout of their car parks.  I mentioned this to the receptionist at the breast care centre, and she said, 'oh, that was done MONTHS ago!'  Huh, I thought to myself - it really is 6 months since I was here, after having practically lived in this place whilst I was having treatment.  Things must be getting better... Seriously, though, I think this is a rather personal thing, and is probably to do with the impact that the treatment/disease has on your life.  There's that very intense time when you can't do anything else other than get through the treatment; then things start to tail off, appointment letters from the hospital arrive less frequently, you don't have to take a shed-load of drugs every day... Perhaps it's something you only realise after it's happened?
Posts.Title: When do you graduate to being a BC SURVIVOR and stop being a patient...

Posts.Content: Dear Siani, this pile of sh*te that is cancer treatment is never easy, but I think that you have had it particularly bad.  You and your husband are very much in one another's pockets, I think, if he is your full time carer, and that may have blurred the boundaries of your relationship.  It's an interesting thing, but when we have rows with our partners, the argument can move from the initial thing we're arguing about (as it might be, the level of activity you are currently able to do) and becomes all about something deeper - or sometimes even it becomes an argument about how we are actually arguing, which always seems depressingly circular.  I'm interested in the way you describe your relationship with your husband as being like rearing a child again.  When children are upset, you can go a very long way towards getting them to calm down by just acknowledging their feelings (even if you aren't going to let them do what they want).  Perhaps your husband has a whole bundle of feelings roiling around inside him that he can't express, and this is why he picks fights with you all the time.  Perhaps he needs you to acknowledge out loud that things are difficult for him, that it sounds as if he is having a hard time too, and that yes, you do rely on him and do appreciate the things he does for you.  I know it's unfair that you have to be the one to change your behaviour when you want him to change his instead, but it is so often the case that, in any interaction between people, the one who has the widest range of behaviour controls the outcome.  In other words, if, when you get into a row, you can resist the temptation to follow the usual script, you could cause the entire argument to have a very different result.   With regard to your pain, I wonder whether your oncology team know exactly how much pain you are in?  I think they may not know, given that they aren't giving you any help with it.  It would be worthwhile starting with your breast care nurse, or with the Macmillan helpline - I know they are often recommended, but that's because they are brilliant and incredibly helpful - and asking them for help with the pain.  Once you have that more under control, you will feel better.   Let us know how you get on.  We are always here.  We will always listen.
Posts.Title: Stupid disease

Posts.Content: Hi there Amsmi, I'm sorry to hear that you are getting the run-around from the medics.  You are of course allowed to be paranoid about this - in some cases, paranoia might just save your life! - and I think you are being very sensible to push for this.  I have everything crossed for you, and I really hope that it isn't the bloody cancer back again.  Keep us posted, huh?
Posts.Title: Back pain and very scared

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera, I'm so sorry to hear of your troubles.  Alison gives very wise advice (as usual!) - especially the bit about the chocolate.  I think that, in the short term, you need to do whatever you need to do to keep your spirits up. Your boyfriend has let you know who he really is by cheating on you.  He's basically told you he's a shit - always useful to know.  I don't know whether you believe in karma or not, but I do, and I think he's set himself up for a monumental karmic smack-down.  Maybe not today or tomorrow, but someday down the line, he'll get his.   When I had my mastectomy, it was described to me as a straightforward physical operation with extremely complex psychological aspects to it.  Some women sail through, and some don't.  I definitely think that you should talk to your breast care nurse - I don't think I had realised when I was going through all the treatment, but they do have such a role in keeping our thoughts on an even keel.  I take it that you have a plan to undergo reconstruction surgery?  I know that it's not the same, but I have spoken to women who feel massively relieved when their reconstructions are done.   Cancer is an incredibly life-changing event, and not necessarily in a good way - it is as if some powerful force takes your life and shakes it violently.  I'm two and a half years from the finish of my treatment, and I still feel the shaking every now and then.  But my life is settling, and I hope yours will too.   Keep talking to us - we understand. Much love
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hello Bubbleblower, welcome, and I'm sorry that your diagnosis has brought you here - although it's great to have you, of course!  If you fancy doing a bit of surfing, try Googling 'Alfie cancer sheep'.  I think it's a fairly uplifting story!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Yay, Ethel, you rock!  What a brilliant thread.  Look at all you have achieved.  I too changed my life when I became ill - I left my hugely stressful and horrible workplace, took redundancy, and set up my own business.  My relationship with my husband became stronger (I suspect that no marriage/partnership remains unchanged!) and we really started to look at what we want out of life, rather than allowing ourselves to drift through.  I feel a lot of relief in many ways.  I now know how strong I am (I always thought of myself as weak - not any more!)  I overcame a dreadful needle phobia.  My decision not to have kids has become irrevocable now, and that's an enormous relief - I hadn't realised how the dread of becoming pregnant had hung over my head before.  And I learned that I can really just get my head down and slog through a bad situation without being overwhelmed.   In a way, I think I needed such a huge kick up the backside to make me change my life so drastically.  I wish it hadn't happened, but actually, on one level, I'm glad I went through it.  (I only hope I don't need to be in receipt of another such kick!!)
Posts.Title: Almost 2 years on - the good things!

Posts.Content: Hi Barbs, I don't have any advice, but what I DO have is a great big whopping hug for you.  I am so sorry that you are going through all of this.
Posts.Title: Help with recurrence

Posts.Content: Hey Marg, I'm really glad to hear that you made the decision to have a night off.  I think this is exactly the right thing to do.  Chemo really does take it out of you, and it's nothing to do with whether you are tough or weak.  I might also suggest that going to a party, with lots of other people there, would not be a good move when you are having chemo.  It does depress your immune system, and you could put yourself at risk of catching something unpleasant.   I hope you're enjoying yourself!  I am watching the Royal Institution Christmas Lecture and I think my brain has just exploded. All the very best
Posts.Title: tired

Posts.Content: Hey Debs, I am sorry that you are still feeling crappy.  It's been a year now since I finished my treatment, and in the month after my chemo, I felt despair that I would never even be able to walk up the stairs again, never mind carry on with my action-packed life.  Things got better, though, and I am now able to do a great deal of the things I could do before.  (I have to say, though, that recovery time has at least doubled... if I have a busy day, I'm pretty shattered the day after!)  We go through so much during treatment, it's hardly surprising that we cannot bounce back in a short time.

Posts.Title: Anybody in the same position?

Posts.Content: Hello there Chloecat I'm sorry that you are in this place where you have to make such decisions.  It's a horrible thing to have to do.  When I had my treatment, I went down both routes and had all the conventional allopathic treatments plus some complementary ones, and I am very happy that I did so.  I did a lot of research, most of which escapes me now I'm afraid.  There was one thing in particular I read - I wish I could remember the name of the book, but it was by Dr Rosy Daniels, who was head of the Bristol Cancer Centre for a long time (now the Penny Brohn centre, I think) and an exponent of holistic treatment for cancer.  She said that she advised patients to never refuse surgery, no matter what other treatments they opted for, because surgery is the single most effective treatment you can have for cancer.   Now, I am hoping that I'm not overstepping the bounds of what I can say on here (I've just been to read the community guidelines and I think I'm OK, but I'm sure a moderator will help me if I'm not).  When I was first diagnosed, I spoke extensively to a lady called Ginny Fraser, who is a close personal friend of a great friend of mine.  If you Google Ginny, you will find out a lot about her and her personal journey through cancer.  I think you might be able to relate to her story, and perhaps it might give you some avenues to explore. I totally believe that we get the best treatment available from the NHS - and the soaring survival rates testify to this.  I also believe that if you think that route's not for you, then you should be able to go down a different one.  At the end of the day, it is our choices and our bodies.  It's also, I believe, a valid choice to say no to treatment altogether (knowing that I could actually say no to any or all of the treatments made it easier, in a strange way, to agree to have them - I hate being forced into things).  But it is an individual path that we follow, and it is not for us to question what others have chosen.   Chloecat, I wish you well.  I wish you didn't have to go through all of this, of course - I wish that for all of us here - and I know you'll make the right decision for you. All the best
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hey Chloecat, I'm glad you are still here, and with some positive results too.  Your approach seems to be working for you, and I'm pleased that you have found this way.  I think your attitude bears out something I really believe about the best way to go through cancer treatment - it is good to be authentic, to deal with our situation in the way which is right for us; which may of course not be right for another person.  Good luck for the rest of your treatment!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Whiskers, we are honoured that you have chosen this place to tell us all about how you feel.  I hope it has made you feel better.  You certainly have had a journey which has been on the tough end of the scale!  I am actually really impressed that you are holding it together as much as you are - that's an achievement in itself.   Appearance varies in importance depending on who we are and what we do.  I wasn't that bothered about how I looked (although I have noticed that I no longer look at my torso, even in the shower) and I was lucky that my hair grew back in a really amazing way, all pewter grey and curly (sadly that didn't last).  It sounds like the hysterectomy is the last straw for you, and means something to you as per your identity as a woman.  I think that, whatever losses we have experienced during this horrible time in our lives, we have to recognise them and mourn them, before we can let them go.  Of course it is hideously unfair that you, at 36, have had to go through all this.  Of course it would have been much better if you hadn't had any of this shit happen to you.  But sadly it has happened, and you are in the middle of it, and those who have not experienced it don't understand, or don't want to understand.  But we understand. Whiskers, here you are heard, and here you can rail to your heart's content.  I wish I had some comforting words for you, about how things will get better, about how your team are working hard on your behalf, about how you will look back on this and realise how strong and capable and amazing you are, to have got through it all.  (And all of those things are true.)  But at the moment, you are fed up and tired and in pain, and it's OK to feel angry and crappy about it.  I am sorry that this is happening to you. Can you talk to your breast care nurse?  It is their job to be the bridge between all the treatments you are undergoing.  Perhaps if they know that you are feeling this way, they can smooth things over a bit for you?
Posts.Title: never ending :(

Posts.Content: Oh, Icy, I'm so terribly sorry to hear about the loss of your dog.  I had a wonderful animal of a very different species who helped me so much during my chemo (that's him in my profile picture!) and when he died this year, 2 years after my treatment finished, it was such a terrible blow.  Your dog must have been a very special friend to you.  I have no idea about the headaches - I think it would be worthwhile ringing your breast care nurse about that - but I can completely understand how devastating the loss of such a friend is.
Posts.Title: Headaches is this normal

Posts.Content: Hi there Emilly, and welcome!  I'm glad to see you here, and very sorry that you're in the circumstances which have led you to join.   No, you're not going mad.  It is a good thing that you are letting yourself cry if that's what you need to do.  FEC and Tax are abbreviations for some very commonly prescribed breast cancer chemo drugs - FEC is a combination of fluorouracil, epirubicin (that's the one that makes your wee red after the treatment!) and cyclophosphamide, and Tax is short for Docetaxol (the brand name for that is Taxotere - it's made from yew trees!  I never walk past a yew tree now without thanking it for saving my life, just in case it donated some leaves.)  The treatment regime I had was 3 FEC, each 3 weeks apart, and then 3 Docetaxol.  I think that's quite a common one to have.   Take care, and keep visiting.  We've all been there, so we understand. Much love,
Posts.Title: So why cant ibstop crying?

Posts.Content: Hey there Lola Well done for finishing your chemo.  You've done brilliantly to get this far.  It's so confusing when you can't get the answers to your questions, and scary too.  I am sure that your mastectomy will deal the fatal blow to that tumour.  I had some cancerous cells left after chemo too (I had a lumpectomy then chemo then a mastectomy), and so I had a lot of worries about the drugs having not worked, but so far I seem to be OK.   I do remember the end of chemo as being a hugely emotional time.  It was as if I had suppressed all of the worry and fear during the treatment, and it all had to come out afterwards.  It's a rollercoaster ride. I'm sending you hugs, and lots of them.  Keep your chin up. Much love,
Posts.Title: So why cant ibstop crying?

Posts.Content: Hey G&J, thank you so much for your encouraging words!  It means a lot to me that you are here.  I'll stockpile the booklet until I feel ready to read it, but I know how brilliant all the Maccy literature is, so I'm sure it'll be really helpful.  I am definitely keeping in mind all our friends here who are dealing with mets, and I hope that I too will get mine under control.  I haven't had radio yet, but I know that's a good treatment for bone pain.  I am certainly hoping I won't have to do the full-blown chemo again, but I expect it'll be on the cards.  At least this time I will know how to handle it. I have to say that a few things have happened over the last few months which made me wonder whether it would come back.  I am quite a superstitious person (I had my life saved by a sheep, so of course I am superstitious!) and I think that with the loss of said sheep, back in July, I felt as if my early warning system had been taken from me.  We've been going through a terrific amount of personal upheaval which has been very unwelcome, too.  But the return of the cancer has cut through a lot of that crap and will hopefully make some decisions easier.   And now I am both exhausted and starving hungry.  In the midst of life we are in death - and in need of a snack. Hugs back atcha
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: My dear friends, I'm so touched by your lovely words and all your encouragement.  I am so glad that I have helped people along the way, and I know that you have all helped me, and will continue to do so I am sure.  We all support one another here, don't we?  I am very happy to hear all the good stories, and I'm particularly pleased that you have replied, Alison - I had hoped you would.  Your story is, at the moment, a talisman that I'm clinging to. I've been watching Lambing Live too, and I always love it.  We aren't lambing our sheep this year (we had been intending to move to Derbyshire for my husband's work, which is obviously on hold now) and I am rather glad we made that decision.  Those lambs on the TV are beyond cute, although obviously not as cute as any of ours from previous years! All the very best, my cancer-butt-kicking friends!
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Hey friends, it's me again.  I have realised that I haven't updated you for a while, so here I am with the latest news.  I have had a CT and a bone scan, which has revealed that I have mets in both the right and left sides of my pelvis (the right is very much worse and the bone's fairly honeycombed), tiny patches on three ribs, and one little bit on my right clavicle.  The scans were fairly traumatic because it is very difficult to find my veins for the cannula and I was pretty scared about that, but the resident expert in the scanning department (a huge shout-out to Patrick, who my friend has dubbed the phlebotomancer because he also managed to take blood from me, a fairly difficult task at the best of times!) managed without any problem.  We then got a call from the hospital again the following day, calling me back in for another CT scan urgently because they spotted some blood clots on my lungs which they wanted to have a closer look at.  After that, I saw one of the oncology doctors, who gave me the good news that the cancer is just in the bones at the moment.  They have also prescribed me daily Fragmin injections for the clots, which will hopefully sort them out.   I went back to see my consultant about 10 days later, and although it was under horrible circumstances, it was lovely to see her again.  I also briefly saw my surgeon in the waiting room, who squeezed my hand and whispered that they have lots of patients in my position who do really well for many years - it was great to hear that from him.  My consultant has prescribed Anastrazole and Zolodex for me, plus the bone strengthening drug whose name never sticks in my mind (begins with D?) and I will be having radiotherapy pretty soon to deal with the pain and get me walking again.  At the moment I am not allowed to do any weight bearing exercise, but they reckon that will change once the treatments kick in.   The consultant asked me what we have done about the sheep, and I said that we have some friends helping us with them at the moment.  She said that she was glad we hadn't done anything rash like selling them, because she was aiming to get me able to look after them again, albeit without any of the heavy lifting.  The breast care nurse said later that the whole team is very motivated to make sure that I have as long with the sheep as I can possibly have, because they know how important they are to me.  But we have lined up a home for them, just in case, and I am sure they will be going there eventually.  It's a lovely place, with a good friend of mine, and I think they'll be happy there.  My horse is being looked after by a lovely lady who I am hoping will take him over completely after a while - I doubt I will ride again now.  My husband is currently keeping his Shetland pony, who I think is proving to be a very helpful support for him.  Husband goes to the farm and spends time just brushing the pony's mane and tail, which is very soothing for both of them! I am very up and down about all of this.  Before I saw the consultant I asked my husband to take away my stock of painkillers and put them somewhere I couldn't get at them - I was worried that the bit of me which can unflinchingly pluck turkeys and wring the necks of chickens might get the upper hand and I would do something that my friends and family would certainly regret.  I think that worried everyone a bit more than it would have done if I were weepy and emotional.  But that urge has now receded since I spoke with the consultant.  I feel I have a future tense, as my friend put it, albeit one the length of which we do not know.  (But then again, none of us know!)  I have got a few projects which I would like to finish, the most important being writing a book about my life with Alfie the famous sheep, so I can't check out just yet.   Good things have come of all this.  Our move to the East Midlands (which I really was unhappy about) has been shelved for the time being.  I have seen a lot more of my friends and family.  One friend in particular, who I was always fond of, has been a complete trooper, visiting me every day and keeping my spirits up.  Even the people who I thought might not feel able to step up have done so.  Some of my friends have formed a Team Sheep rota, where they each go to the farm one day a week and check the flock, and I'm surprised at how much pleasure that is giving them.  Because it's just my life, I forget how unusual a thing it is for a non-agricultural person to get out in the open air and interact with that group of charmers which is my flock.  My life has streamlined, and I have a direction again, which is to just do the treatments for this latest setback and to deal with being ill, which I realise now that I am actually very good at.   The ghost of Alfie the sheep is always there with me, especially in the hospital where, it turns out, I am the most famous (or notorious?) patient in the breast centre.  They did all know that he had died, and every single person who knew me from the first time round has quietly said how sad they were when they heard.  I had a piece of his fleece clutched in my hand whilst going through all the scanners, and even though he's not around any more, he's still doing the job of making sure that everyone remembers me - it's a very useful thing!   So I think that's it.  I am still just in a holding pattern, waiting for the radiotherapy to start - I'm seeing the consultant for that on 1st May - and then we will find out where we go from there.  I might not be on here all that often, but I will pop back every now and then and keep you posted. Much love to all of you, my friends, and may the Power of the Miracle Sheep (as some of the papers put it) be with you!
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Dear friends I'm afraid that I'm now in a position to need your help and support.  I've been having some problems with one of my hips, and the x-ray that was taken last week showed that I've got some mets in the bone there.  I heard the news at lunchtime, and I'm a little foggy as to what's going to happen next - they want to get on top of the pain I'm in, which is pretty severe (I can't walk) and then they're going to do a bone scan to see what the actual situation is.  I have been talking talking talking to my family and friends this afternoon, letting them know what's going on, and this is the first chance I've had to actually take a breath and go 'fuck, I've got stage 4 cancer'.  I know that several of you are in a similar position, and I wanted to reach out and make contact with you, see if you have any words of advice or encouragement for me. Basically, it's utterly shite, and I'm trying very hard to contain my natural instinct to scream and tear my hair out.  But that too will pass. Much love
