Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Hi there H! Sorry to find you here.  I certainly hope that they get you back in and tell you that it's nothing!  Pre-cancerous cells are certainly A Thing (I had many, many of them!) I also had some which had achieved their ambition to become real live cancer cells... they got what was coming to them during my treatment!  I'd like to just give you a little bit of useful advice which I wish I'd been told right at the start - Google is Not Your Friend under these circumstances!  If you feel as if you want to research the mechanics of cancer and the treatment, I would recommend that you stick to this site, which is super comprehensive.  There's a lot of scary info out there, you don't know if it applies to you, and anyway, I find that seeing 563,499,000,000 Google hits all about cancer gives me the collywobbles.  The Macmillan support line is also an excellent resource if you want to talk to someone knowledgeable about all of this. There's usually a bit of waiting around for tests, results etc. in the early stages of this sort of thing.  It can be wearing on the nerves, and we all have our ways of getting our heads around it.  There's no right or wrong way to do it! Good luck, keep us posted. All the best!
Posts.Title: Undiagnosed and waiting………..

Posts.Content: Hey H, don't worry, I really didn't think you were trivialising pre-cancerous cells - I didn't get that at all from your post.  I had never heard of them before either!  Mine definitely had to go, because they were cells with ambition, and would have become fully fledged cancerous cells before too long. I think that the reason I empathise with your situation is that I remember when I was at the same stage of the "journey".  By the time I knew for certain what I was dealing with, I had put in a lot of worrying time.  Those couple of weeks would have been just as horrible if, at the end, they'd said to me 'Oh well, it's nothing, off you go, and don't listen to sheep when they tell you you've got cancer, because they're often wrong' (see my profile for the low-down on that one!)  It is weird, but for so many of us, the early days are the absolute worst.  Actually, when I did know what I was dealing with, I worried less. You will undoubtedly feel as if you're on a rollercoaster, and as you have observed, that's OK.  We understand!  We've been on it, and survived to tell the tale.  So will you! All the best
Posts.Title: Undiagnosed and waiting………..

Posts.Content: My dear friends, I am humbled and touched by your good wishes.  This forum is truly a boon!  My friends in real life have rallied round, I have managed to find someone to help with my horse (who I love dearly and may well never ride again), and I haven't yet seen the sheep - but once my wheelchair arrives tomorrow I will make a real effort to get out and about!  My pain isn't quite under control yet, but I do have an addition to my prescription which should help.  Sadly, GillieB, I can't drink when I'm taking it, which is gutting because I LOVELOVELOVE gin and would be delighted to have a nice crisp G&T in my hand right now.  You'll have to have one for me.   I'm in a holding pattern right now, trying hard not to think of what is to come - really because I just have no idea.  I have an active imagination, which I'm trying not to exercise.  Since I was ill the first time out, I have never really looked very far ahead in my life - 5 months is about the furthest I have planned for (the gestation period of sheep!)  This skill might stand me in good stead. Much love to you all.  Thank you for your kind words.
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: I feel the same way.  The salient fact which hardly any reports are mentioning (although the BBC news channel did say this) is that it's impossible at the moment to tell which cancers are the ones which will just sit there and behave themselves, and which are the ones which will go on the rampage.  And I seem to remember reading something else which said that quiet and well-behaved cancers can be triggered to become more aggressive, and they don't understand why that happens either.   Mine was a pretty aggressive customer, certainly, and I was glad to get rid of it - and it wasn't found through screening, either, more through a very weird accident.  I don't think, though, that I'd have been comfortable leaving it in place, even if there'd been a chance that it would not have grown any further...
Posts.Title: BBC Report

Posts.Content: How frustrating, to have more information and it not be The Information you need.  But at least they are getting everyone involved in working out what the problem is, so you've got all that combined expertise working for you.  I think what you do on Friday really depends on you, whether you take someone or not.  I would take someone with me, but that's just me.  If you are on your own, I'm sure that they'll make sure there is someone with you who can give you support. Let us know what happens - I'll be thinking of you on Friday and sending you good, non-cancerous vibes. All the best
Posts.Title: Undiagnosed and waiting………..

Posts.Content: Well done on getting through your first chemo!  That's one ticked off the list.  I think it's quite hard to get your head around what's happening to you the first time out, because it's all so new.  I found the first one very scary, and although I didn't feel any better after subsequent ones, at least i understood what was happening and knew that there was a rhythm to it.  That made it easier to cope.  If you are worried about anything to do with the chemo, it's worth talking to someone about it - your breast care nurse is a good starting point, or you may have been given some phone numbers by the chemo nurses.   Good luck.  You've started now, and it won't be long until you have finished! Much love
Posts.Title: after effects chemo

Posts.Content: Hello H My treatment finished over 2 years ago now, and I've not been troubled by those pesky cells since.  I had a lumpectomy, chemo, and then a mastectomy, but no radiotherapy.  I'm pretty much back to where I was (although my eyebrows have gone AWOL!) and I'm feeling fairly good, if stressed through other things at the moment (we are moving house, and I can tell you that moving 200 miles with a flock of sheep to accommodate is Extremely Stressful!)   Soooo... preparation for your appointment.  Are you able to take someone else in with you?  That is always worth doing.  They can remember things that you don't, and can remind you to ask stuff if you forget.  It's worth remembering that, although this is a big and terrible ordeal for you, your oncology team see people having to come to terms with this sort of thing all the time, so they will be aware that it is difficult, and that you will have questions which may not come to your mind straight away.  See if they give you any literature - I was given some superb leaflets from the charity Breast Cancer Care which were really comprehensive.   If it turns out that you do have cancer, obviously you'll want to ask ALL THE QUESTIONS straight away, but you will find that this is the start of a lengthy relationship with your oncology team, and there is always someone at the end of the phone to talk to you (that's what a Breast Care Nurse's job involves).  You will also find that things will move surprisingly fast.  You'll be seeing quite a lot of the inside of your local hospital, so there will be plenty of opportunities to fill in the gaps.   You might want to give some consideration to whether you want to know the stats.  Some people want to know all the percentages, some don't.  It is worth deciding that right at the start, because then you can stick your fingers in your ears if anyone broaches this subject!  I asked my surgeon whether there was any reason why I shouldn't be in the 'complete cure and never troubled by it again' group, and he said, 'no, you're very boringly routine I'm afraid, nothing unusual about you - apart from the sheep of course'.  I didn't want to know anything else about the survival stats.  (Remember, too, that 5 and 10 year survival rates measure the success of treatments 5 and 10 years ago!) How comfortable you are with your medical team will definitely help or hinder you in getting information.  My surgeon was brilliant, my oncologists were fantastic, and I trusted them all implicitly.  They never let me believe something that turned out not to be true, and they were always right about what they thought would happen.  That meant that I threw myself entirely on their knowledge, and let them do their job. It was the right thing to do for me. I'm sure some of the others will weigh in with their own thoughts.  I really hope that you get good news when you go for your appointment - and if you do, I and the sheep will dance around the field in your honour! All the best

Posts.Content: Hey Orangetulip I'm sorry that things are so overwhelming for you right now.  The one thing that helped me most when I went through my treatment 2 and a bit years ago was the realisation that I had a choice.  You could actually go to your oncologist and say "you know what?  I don't want to have any chemo, thanks."  You could refuse any or all of your treatments.  You could walk out of the hospital right now and not go back.  I chose to have all the treatments on offer, but the knowledge that I could have said no somehow helped me.  It was as if, by taking the time to make that decision, I stopped the merry-go-round for a few moments, and then started it again myself.   You know, if you get a wig, all that means is that you've got a wig.  You might not lose your hair - that happened to someone I went through treatment with.  You might get the most knockout wig on the planet which makes you smile every time you put it on (I wanted a pink one, but I never managed to find one).  I didn't enjoy the being bald, but once I had my wig on, not only did it fool everyone else, but it kind of fooled me, too.  I never looked at myself in the mirror without it on, and I was able to apply a healthy sort of denial to the whole thing.  (And when my hair grew back, it was AWESOME.  Pity it went back to what I had before, very dull.) I remember the early time, when you're waiting for the results of tests and you have the spectre of chemo looming on the horizon, as being the most scary time.  Once you set off on the path you choose to take, whatever that is, things will get better.  And we are here for you. PS.  I'm not recommending that you actually refuse treatments, of course!  What I'm saying is that you just recognise that you could.

Posts.Content: Hello Amy I think if we are anxious about things like this, we notice them more anyway.  I'm quite a worrier myself, and I know how hard it is to get it under control.  My mind likes to run away with me and have all these outlandish thoughts which, when I examine them rationally, are really complete works of fiction.  But they don't half seem real at the time.  Then I start getting anxious about being anxious... and round and round we go.   I hope you can soon find out what the issue is (or indeed whether it is an issue at all) and that the knowledge will put your mind at rest. All the very best to you, Amy, and good wishes for the coming year!
Posts.Title: Still Trying Not To Panic!

Posts.Content: Well, Amy, have you actually lifted anything heavy recently?  Do you have the sort of job or hobby where you're lifting things, or twisting and stretching a lot?  I'm a shepherd, so I tend to do quite a bit of that sort of thing.  I strained a muscle in my chest wall in the summer, and when I went for my annual check-up with the oncologist, she noticed a ropy sort of lump in my chest and got me to have a mammogram to check it out.  By the time my appointment came through, the lump had disappeared and I could move my arms more freely, so it was all fine.   We have lymph nodes at different depths within the armpit - some are quite close to the surface, some are deeper in, so your GP probably wouldn't be able to feel all of them.  That might be why he couldn't say whether they were swollen or not.   I hear your panic and worry, Amy, and I'm sorry that you are so concerned.  I am not sure that self-diagnosis is particularly helpful (or accurate!) though.  Whatever it turns out to be, you will be OK - a well-oiled machine will swing into action for you if it turns out that you do have something sinister, and you will be guided down the path by experts who have taken the journey with many, many people before.  And if you don't have something sinister, then you'll be able to look back on this as a scare which came to nothing.   Can I recommend that you phone the Macmillan Support Line?  The phone number is all over the site.  They're open office hours, and you will be able to speak with someone who is knowledgeable about cancer and will be able to talk more authoritatively than we can.  (But we are here for moral support too!) Just breathe, remind yourself that the majority of lumps in breasts are benign, and go and do your favourite calming activity.  (Mine is knitting.)  All will be well, and all manner of things will be well.  I have confidence that you will be absolutely fine. Much love

Posts.Content: Oh, my dear Kay, I am so sad that you feel that you are a fraud.  You've gone through the mill the same as the rest of us.  DCIS might not be the same as having invasive cancer... at the moment, but give it time, untreated, and it could become invasive.  You have done well to nail it early.   I didn't have radiotherapy nor do I need Herceptin, but otherwise I've marked off most of the usual treatments on the BC Bingo Card.  (I haven't had a reconstruction, either - too much of a coward to go through all that surgery.)  But I mean, honestly, it's not like you have to get a full house to say that you've REALLY had cancer.  You have had your ordeal, and it's been as much of an ordeal as anyone else's.   Take gentle care of yourself.  You're not a fraud.  You've been through the initiation, same as the rest of us.  You're an official survivor now.

Posts.Content: Hello Jan Yup, completely normal to feel THE DREAD.  If it is any comfort, waiting for the scans and the results from them is, I think, the most unsettling time.  Once you start having the treatment, then you just get into the groove and away you go.  And the more contact your team have with you, the better they know you, and the better they will know how to help you.  I am impressed that you have managed to be calm in the face of all this that's going on for you right now - perhaps, though, a good scream would help?  It might well actually do you some good.  (I also recommend bad language, but that might just be me.)   Many of the regular posters on here will recommend that you ring the Macmillan Support Line if you are at all worried or stressed.  I got through my entire treatment, 2 years ago, without doing that, but during a very low period in the summer, I did phone them, and they were fantastically helpful.  Even if you don't have a specific question as such, you can just talk over the issues with someone who gets it completely.   I am sorry that you have all this confusion over dates.  I hope that things will smooth out soon.  I will be thinking of you.

Posts.Content: I have quite a selection of domestic animals sharing my life with me (but no dog, actually!), so I was very keen to get advice from my consultant when I started my chemo treatment.  She told me that I could be excused from mucking out the horses (yay!!) and I should be very careful around poo and dirt, but that actually I was at much more risk from other human beings than from the animals.  All my creatures were very careful around me when I was feeling fragile - my poor horse never got over his fright when he whiffled my wig off and discovered my bald head, though! - and I didn't empty the litter tray for the cats, muck out the horses, or do any of the heavy shepherding stuff.  There are comparatively few diseases that horses, sheep and cats can get which they can transmit to you, and I rather liked the idea that I was safer with them than I was around other humans.

Posts.Content: Dear Mccaan Firstly, WELL DONE for getting through the ordeal of your treatment.  And it is an ordeal, a hard, long, draining endurance test which you have completed.  I am so sorry to hear that you haven't got support at home.  Cancer doesn't just happen to us; it impacts on the web of relationships which we have, and unfortunately some people don't cope very well with the whole situation.  Many of us on here have found this to be true.   I know that you'll get recommendations to ring the Support Line here at Macmillan.  I was a bit wary of doing so until this year, but I am so glad that I finally made that call.  I was astonished at how much better I felt.  I would say that it is the best first step you can make.   As for wanting everything to be back to normal - I'm not entirely sure this is possible.  You cannot forget the treatment you have gone through, or undo the experiences you have had.  It's a bit like going through the looking glass, or travelling to another planet - you return changed.  I found that the physical recovery was one thing, but getting my head around what happened to me was quite another.   I'm not sure I have any really great advice for you (apart from ring the support line!) but I just wanted to say that you are not alone, you do have friends to talk to (that'll be us) and you are amongst your tribe here, people who understand what has happened to you.  You deserve to have a good rant to your friends, and we will listen.   Much love

Posts.Content: Hey folks I'm taking part in the Supremo trial, but I'm in the non-radiotherapy arm of it.  Like many of us, I would not have qualified for radiotherapy in the usual way of things, and my oncologist told me that if she thought it would have definitely benefitted me, then I would have had it.  As it turned out, I'm not having the treatment anyway, having been randomly selected not to undergo it.  If I had had the radiotherapy, I'd have been OK with that, too, having decided that I would throw everything available at the cancer.  It is a very personal decision, I think, whether to participate in something like that; you have to weigh up the pros and cons for you (which might well be different to anyone else's!)
